story:
It is with great pride that the National Museum of Nuclear Science & History's staff and Board of Trustees announce that through generous support received through Indiegogo and donations that came directly to the museum, we have received the $110,000 to complete the restoration of the B-47E Stratojet!

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Help bring an iconic piece of history back to life!

The congressionally chartered, Smithsonian affiliated National Museum of Nuclear Science & History - a non-profit museum located in Albuquerque, New Mexico - is restoring its iconic B-47E Stratojet, serial number 53-2280.

This restoration initiative is a special project within Operation Preservation, an ongoing campaign to repaint and refurbish the iconic aircraft in the National Museum of Nuclear Science & History's nine-acre outdoor exhibit area, Heritage Park. 

The museum's historic B-47E Stratojet - one of only 23 surviving B-47 airplanes in existence - has experienced the ravages of the Southwestern weather, and we would like to ask for your support in paying for the surface preparation and painting of the exterior of the aircraft. 

By restoring the B-47E Stratojet, we hope to connect museum visitors - both present and future - with this pivotal piece of history, and celebrate its many contributions to the United States Air Force and modern day jet airliners.

The total restoration cost for this airplane is expected to be $110,000. A little less than half will be paid by this Indiegogo project. The money raised in this campaign will be used for the cosmetic restoration of the fuselage and wings on the aircraft. That is, to purchase the paint ($460) per gallon and primer ($300 per gallon), prepare the airplane's surface and then paint the fuselages and wings.

The reason why the primer and paint for this project are so expensive is the paint must last a long time. In the Southwest region of the United States, normal paint or even MilSpec paint is only good for 3-5 years. The NAPA premium automotive primer and finish we will use is guaranteed for 15-20 years. In addition, we must choose a paint and a color that is approved by the United States Air Force and other museum entities.

The B-47E will receive trim and insignia to look like a Strategic Air Command bomber from the late 1950s to the mid-1960s. Restoration of the aircraft will begin in Spring of 2018 under the supervision of Brigadier General (Ret.) Jay Bledsoe, Restoration Project Manager, with the help from museum staff and volunteers. Jay has successfully managed the restoration of two of the museum's other airplanes, the F-105D Thunderchief and the A-7 Corsair II.

With a quickly approaching target completion date for the restoration of the B-47E of August, 2018, we ask you to please consider becoming a member of the National Museum of Nuclear Science & History's B-47E Stratojet Restoration Team by making a donation through Indiegogo! As a part of this support team, you will personally help in the preservation of this iconic airplane.

 

About the B-47E Stratojet

A flight line of B-47Es on a SAC base.

The B-47 Stratojet, with a wing span of 116 feet, was a long-range, six-engine, jet-powered strategic bomber designed to fly at high subsonic speeds and at high altitudes to avoid enemy interception. The B-47's mission was primarily to deliver nuclear ordnance on designated targets. With its engines carried in pods under the swept wing, the B-47 was a major innovation in post-World War II combat jet design and helped lead to modern jet airliners.

The B-47 never saw combat as a bomber, but it was a mainstay of the United States Air Force’s Strategic Air Command’s (SAC) strength during the 1950s and early 1960s, and it remained in use as a bomber until 1965. It was also adapted to a number of other missions, including photo reconnaissance, electronic intelligence and weather reconnaissance, remaining in service as a reconnaissance platform until 1969 and as a test bed until 1977.

Historical photograph of a B-47 Stratojet in the air.

Boeing JB-47E-110-BW (S/N 53-2280) landing with deceleration parachute. Photo taken August 12, 1957, during a test conducted by the Wright Air Development Center. (United States Air Force photo) ​

The B-47E – the type of aircraft located at the National Museum of Nuclear Science & History - was an improved version of the B model and more than 1,500 were produced by Boeing, Douglas and Lockheed. Improvements incorporated into the E model Stratojet included a more powerful version of the General Electric J47 turbojet and Rocket Assisted Take Off packs with 18 or 33 rockets that were jettisoned after use. Other features of the B-47E included 20mm cannons in the tail instead of the .50-cal. machine guns of the B model and upgraded avionics.

The National Museum of Nuclear Science & History’s B-47E Stratojet – on permanent loan from the National Museum of the United States Air Force (USAF) - came out of the Boeing, Wichita, Kansas plant on March 1st 1955. The aircraft served most of its operational life as a test bed for modern “fly-by-wire” (FBW) systems. This system replaced conventional manual flight controls of an aircraft with an electronic interface. The B-47E was removed from inventory at Wright Patterson AFB in Dayton, Ohio, in 1969 and was transferred to the USAF Heritage Museum program where it stayed until 2003. It was then moved into storage outside the museum’s restoration hangars until it was moved from Dayton, Ohio, to the National Museum of Nuclear Science & History in August of 2013.

 

Who We Are

The National Museum of Nuclear Science & History is a Smithsonian Affiliate and is the nation's only congressionally chartered museum in its field. The museum is nationally accredited through the American Alliance of Museums and is also a member of the Association of Science-Technology Centers. The National Museum of Nuclear Science & History is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization.

The National Museum of Nuclear Science & History was established in 1969 as an intriguing place to learn the story of the Atomic Age, from early research of nuclear development through today’s peaceful uses of nuclear technology. The museum strives to present, through permanent and changing exhibits and displays, the diverse applications of nuclear energy in the past, present and future along with the stories of the field’s pioneers.

This 30,000-sq-ft building and nine-acre outdoor exhibit area display artifacts from Geiger counters, historic medical devices and items from the Manhattan Project to vintage comic books, nostalgic toys and a B-29 Superfortress. The major interior exhibits include Nano, Pioneers of the Atom, Trinity and its Legacy, Hiroshima and Nagasaki, the Cold War, Energy Encounter, Nuclear Medicine, Radiation 101 and more. The Museum also hosts Little Albert’s Lab, an area where young, inquisitive minds can explore hands-on science activities.

Heritage Park, the museum’s nine-acre outdoor exhibit area, is one of the National Museum of Nuclear Science & History’s most popular attractions. With its B-52B Stratofortress, B-29 Superfortress, B-47E Stratojet, F-105D Thunderchief, A-7 Corsair II and F-16 Fighting Falcon, the museum’s collection is the largest aircraft collection for public viewing in the state of New Mexico.

The museum’s mission is “to serve as America’s resource for nuclear history and science. The museum presents exhibits and quality educational programs that convey the diversity of individuals and events that shape the historical and technical context of the nuclear age.” It is truly a place to learn, to imagine, to think and to draw your own conclusions.

 

Our Success Stories

F-105D Thunderchief and the A-7 Corsair II

Our museum's F-105D Thunderchief before Restoration.

Our museum's F-105D Thunderchief after restoration.

Our museum's A-7 Corsair II before restoration.

Our museum's A-7 Corsair II after restoration.

The most current example of the museum's aircraft restoration work can be seen in last year's Operation Preservation project that involved restoring our F-105D Thunderchief and the A-7 Corsair II. Our museum's historic F-105D Thunderchief is a supersonic fighter-bomber that was sent to Germany to provide NATO nuclear retaliation capability during the depths of the Cold War, and the museum's A-7 Corsair II is one of the Navy's most capable attack aircraft that is also the only aircraft in the museum's collection to have ever flown in combat missions.

Restoration of the two aircraft began in April of 2017 under the supervision of Restoration Project Coordinator, Brigadier General (Ret.) Jay Bledsoe, with help from museum staff and volunteers and was funded by donations received from supporters and entities with personal ties to the Museum and the historic aircraft. The museum also successfully raised over $45,000 through multiple initiatives, including an Indiegogo campaign, special events and generous support from donors and organizations. 

Restoration included the F-105D Thunderchief and the A-7 Corsair II receiving bodywork and new coats of primer and paint. Completion of these outdoor exhibits for visitor viewing took place in Winter of 2018. 

 

B-52B Stratofortress

Our museum's B-52B Stratofortress before restoration.

Our museum's B-52B Stratofortress after restoration.

The museum successfully restored its B-52B Stratofortress, s/n 52-0013, one of only a few B-models left in existence and one of only four in the world on display for public viewing, in the fall of 2016. Restoration of the B-52B began in April of 2016 under the supervision of Restoration Project Coordinator, Major Jerry Hanks, USMC (Retired), with help from museum staff and volunteers and was funded by donations received from supporters and entities with personal ties to the museum and the historic aircraft. The museum also successfully raised over $120,000 through multiple initiatives, including an Indiegogo campaign, special events and generous support from donors and organizations. 

Restoration included the B-52B receiving bodywork and a new coat of primer and paint. Completion of this outdoor exhibit for visitor viewing took place in September 2016. The museum held a dedication ceremony on Thursday, October 13, 2016, where dignitaries were present to publicly acknowledge the legacy and historical significance of the B-52B Stratofortress.

 

B-29 Superfortress

Our museum's B-29 Superfortress before restoration.

Our museum's B-29 Superfortress after restoration.

The museum successfully restored its B-29 Superfortress, one of only 17 complete aircraft of its kind left in existence, in the fall of 2015. Restoration of the B-29 began in April of 2015 under the supervision of Restoration Project Coordinator, Major Jerry Hanks, USMC (Retired), with help from museum staff and volunteers and was funded by donations received from supporters and entities with personal ties to the Museum and the historic aircraft. The museum also successfully raised over $44,000 (part of the overall cost of $110,000 needed) through a Kickstarter campaign to pay for paint and primer.

Restoration included the B-29 receiving a new coat of primer and paint, bodywork to the aircraft, new cockpit windows and the vintage 509th Wing of the Strategic Air Command paint and trim. 

The museum held a dedication ceremony on Tuesday, August 11, 2015, where dignitaries were present to publicly acknowledge the legacy and historical significance of the B-29 Superfortress.

 

F-16 Fighting Falcon

Our museum's F-16 Fighting Falcon before restoration.

Our museum's F-16 Fighting Falcon after restoration.

The museum successfully restored its F-16 Fighting Falcon in the fall of 2014. F-16 Fighting Falcons were flown by the ‘The TACOS’, the New Mexico Air National Guard 150th Fighter Wing. It was rescued from the Sandia National Laboratories Rocket Sled Track and restored for static display. The restoration included the TACO trim and tail insignia to acknowledge the 50+ year legacy and historical significance of the TACOS. The restoration even included lighting the aircraft's navigation, vertical tail illumination and landing lights.

Restoration of this iconic aircraft was supervised by Restoration Project Coordinator, Major Jerry Hanks, USMC (Retired), and was completed with the help of volunteers from Sandia National Laboratories, Kirtland Air Force Base, Museum volunteers and members of the CNM Aviation Maintenance Technology program and Service-Learning program.

The Museum held a dedication ceremony for the newly restored F-16 on November 5, 2014. U.S. Senator Martin Heinrich; U.S. Senator Tom Udall; and Brigadier General Andrew Salas, Adjutant General for the New Mexico Air National Guard were present to publicly acknowledge the restoration as well as the legacy and historical significance of the TACOS.

 

USS James K. Polk Submarine Sail

Our museum's submarine sail during restoration.

Our museum's submarine sail after restoration.

The National Museum of Nuclear Science & History successfully completed the restoration of the iconic USS James K. Polk SSN 645 nuclear submarine sail in the fall of 2014.

This truly historic object, measuring 30 feet high by nine feet wide and weighing 53 tons, was acquired by the Museum in 1999, and restoration began in the spring of 2014. Named after the 11th president of the United States, the USS James K. Polk was commissioned as SSBN 645 in 1966. The James K Polk was later converted into an attack submarine and re-designated SSN 645, making for an illustrious 33-year career.

Under the supervision of Frank Fernando, retired Process Engineer from Intel, and with help from Museum staff, volunteers and various partners, the submarine exhibit was a hub of activity throughout the summer of 2014. The completed submarine sail is now on permanent display in the Museum’s Heritage Park.

 

The Excitement

"Our B-47E is an example of the world's first swept wing jet-powered aircraft and the innovations that were created when it was invented are still with us. The B-47 represents the early jet age and the higher alert of our world during the cold war.​ It is with great excitement we move forward with this huge restoration." - Museum Executive Director, Jim Walther

"I love to see our airplanes returned to their former glory! Our B-47 is an iconic airplane; a strategic nuclear bomber that was flown at high altitude and subsonic speed by the United States Air Force Strategic Air Command. Of the 2032 Stratojets built by Boeing, only 23 survive today. Our aircraft restoration projects are an exciting way to motivate children and adults to be excited about history, science, technology, engineering and math." - Museum Registrar, Sandy Fye

"Some of my earliest recollections, beside chasing after various desert creatures, playing in our back yard grass, and gathering with multiple neighborhood kids to play, include watching the entire wing of USAF’s 303rd Bomb Wing, flying B-47’s based at Davis Monthan AFB, sequentially start engines, squadron-by-squadron and takeoff for a long deployment. Since my father was the navigator of one of these beasts, scheduled to deploy with the entire wing to Guam for training, my mother took me and my siblings to the base to watch the mass departure.

Other wives and mothers were likewise attending while stewarding their charges as congruently as my Mom and in the same viewing area set up for this event. And what a spectacle it was! Each of the three squadrons had a different colored stripe on the tail, to denote that squadron, added color to the show. Start-up sounds of the 270 engines of the 45 aircraft were deafening. Slowly but deliberately, the sleek bombers taxied out to the runway for takeoff. One jet at a time, the silver-colored spears rolled down the long runway, eventually lifting off, trailing six streams of black smoke as they followed one after the other, roaring into the distant Arizona morning sky. Jet after silver jet blasted down the runway, lifting and following the same path to join together many miles away and far from our sight.

Perhaps this is one reason I decided to become a USAF pilot many years later, flying into this same grey-blue sky; off to adventure, challenge, and danger, just as these B-47 crews did some 30 years before, I was flying jets that only a vivid imagination could conjure back in 1957. The B-47’s were retired many years ago, yet the B-47 still holds a vivid and special place in my memory." - Jay Bledsoe, Brig Gen, USAF (Ret)​

 

Your Support, Our Gratitude

The National Museum of Nuclear Science & History staff, Board of Trustees and volunteers all passionately believe in the mission of our museum, and we know its past and future success depends on the generosity of our donors, volunteers and supporters.  Our heartfelt thanks go out to all of you.

Operation Preservation, The Campaign to Restore the Planes in Heritage Park is a massive undertaking, with the B-47E Stratojet being only one of the seven aircraft needing to be restored.  It would be impossible for the museum to consider such a project without the confidence that generous donors will supply the bulk of the funding, and generous volunteers will supply the thousands of man-hours necessary to restore the aircraft. 

Thank you all.

 

Risks & Challenges

The largest risk to this project is in not having the aircraft sufficiently restored so that it can be dedicated in the Fall of 2018. At a minimum, this means the aircraft must be fully painted. For this to happen, the funding must be secured, the body work must be completed, the primer and paint applied and insignias painted.

Mitigation strategies that have been put in place include a schedule that includes time for unknowns such as weather and fluctuation in manpower. In addition, work to secure funds and manpower was started in mid-2017.

Overall, there is little risk that the project will not be completed. The restoration of the B-47E Stratojet is the museum's top priority in 2018, and the museum has an excellent track record of completing aircraft projects. The largest, completed between 2009 and 2011, was the relocation of all aircraft and other Heritage Park exhibits from the museum's first home, when it was located on Kirtland Air Force Base, to its current location. More recently, the museum successfully completed the full restoration of the F-105D Thunderchief, the A-7 Corsair II, the B-52B Stratofortress, the B-29 Superfortress, the F-16 Fighting Falcon and the USS James K. Polk SSN 645 nuclear submarine sail.

 

Thank you for your time and consideration!
story_txt:
It is with great pride that the National Museum of Nuclear Science & History's staff and Board of Trustees announce that through generous support received through Indiegogo and donations that came directly to the museum, we have received the $110,000 to complete the restoration of the B-47E Stratojet!
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Help bring an iconic piece of history back to life!
The congressionally chartered, Smithsonian affiliated National Museum of Nuclear Science & History - a non-profit museum located in Albuquerque, New Mexico - is restoring its iconic B-47E Stratojet, serial number 53-2280.
This restoration initiative is a special project within Operation Preservation, an ongoing campaign to repaint and refurbish the iconic aircraft in the National Museum of Nuclear Science & History's nine-acre outdoor exhibit area, Heritage Park. 
The museum's historic B-47E Stratojet - one of only 23 surviving B-47 airplanes in existence - has experienced the ravages of the Southwestern weather, and we would like to ask for your support in paying for the surface preparation and painting of the exterior of the aircraft. 
By restoring the B-47E Stratojet, we hope to connect museum visitors - both present and future - with this pivotal piece of history, and celebrate its many contributions to the United States Air Force and modern day jet airliners.


The total restoration cost for this airplane is expected to be $110,000. A little less than half will be paid by this Indiegogo project. The money raised in this campaign will be used for the cosmetic restoration of the fuselage and wings on the aircraft. That is, to purchase the paint ($460) per gallon and primer ($300 per gallon), prepare the airplane's surface and then paint the fuselages and wings.
The reason why the primer and paint for this project are so expensive is the paint must last a long time. In the Southwest region of the United States, normal paint or even MilSpec paint is only good for 3-5 years. The NAPA premium automotive primer and finish we will use is guaranteed for 15-20 years. In addition, we must choose a paint and a color that is approved by the United States Air Force and other museum entities.

The B-47E will receive trim and insignia to look like a Strategic Air Command bomber from the late 1950s to the mid-1960s. Restoration of the aircraft will begin in Spring of 2018 under the supervision of Brigadier General (Ret.) Jay Bledsoe, Restoration Project Manager, with the help from museum staff and volunteers. Jay has successfully managed the restoration of two of the museum's other airplanes, the F-105D Thunderchief and the A-7 Corsair II.
With a quickly approaching target completion date for the restoration of the B-47E of August, 2018, we ask you to please consider becoming a member of the National Museum of Nuclear Science & History's B-47E Stratojet Restoration Team by making a donation through Indiegogo! As a part of this support team, you will personally help in the preservation of this iconic airplane.

 
About the B-47E Stratojet

A flight line of B-47Es on a SAC base.
The B-47 Stratojet, with a wing span of 116 feet, was a long-range, six-engine, jet-powered strategic bomber designed to fly at high subsonic speeds and at high altitudes to avoid enemy interception. The B-47's mission was primarily to deliver nuclear ordnance on designated targets. With its engines carried in pods under the swept wing, the B-47 was a major innovation in post-World War II combat jet design and helped lead to modern jet airliners.
The B-47 never saw combat as a bomber, but it was a mainstay of the United States Air Force’s Strategic Air Command’s (SAC) strength during the 1950s and early 1960s, and it remained in use as a bomber until 1965. It was also adapted to a number of other missions, including photo reconnaissance, electronic intelligence and weather reconnaissance, remaining in service as a reconnaissance platform until 1969 and as a test bed until 1977.

Historical photograph of a B-47 Stratojet in the air.

Boeing JB-47E-110-BW (S/N 53-2280) landing with deceleration parachute. Photo taken August 12, 1957, during a test conducted by the Wright Air Development Center. (United States Air Force photo) ​
The B-47E – the type of aircraft located at the National Museum of Nuclear Science & History - was an improved version of the B model and more than 1,500 were produced by Boeing, Douglas and Lockheed. Improvements incorporated into the E model Stratojet included a more powerful version of the General Electric J47 turbojet and Rocket Assisted Take Off packs with 18 or 33 rockets that were jettisoned after use. Other features of the B-47E included 20mm cannons in the tail instead of the .50-cal. machine guns of the B model and upgraded avionics.
The National Museum of Nuclear Science & History’s B-47E Stratojet – on permanent loan from the National Museum of the United States Air Force (USAF) - came out of the Boeing, Wichita, Kansas plant on March 1st 1955. The aircraft served most of its operational life as a test bed for modern “fly-by-wire” (FBW) systems. This system replaced conventional manual flight controls of an aircraft with an electronic interface. The B-47E was removed from inventory at Wright Patterson AFB in Dayton, Ohio, in 1969 and was transferred to the USAF Heritage Museum program where it stayed until 2003. It was then moved into storage outside the museum’s restoration hangars until it was moved from Dayton, Ohio, to the National Museum of Nuclear Science & History in August of 2013.
 
Who We Are

The National Museum of Nuclear Science & History is a Smithsonian Affiliate and is the nation's only congressionally chartered museum in its field. The museum is nationally accredited through the American Alliance of Museums and is also a member of the Association of Science-Technology Centers. The National Museum of Nuclear Science & History is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization.
The National Museum of Nuclear Science & History was established in 1969 as an intriguing place to learn the story of the Atomic Age, from early research of nuclear development through today’s peaceful uses of nuclear technology. The museum strives to present, through permanent and changing exhibits and displays, the diverse applications of nuclear energy in the past, present and future along with the stories of the field’s pioneers.
This 30,000-sq-ft building and nine-acre outdoor exhibit area display artifacts from Geiger counters, historic medical devices and items from the Manhattan Project to vintage comic books, nostalgic toys and a B-29 Superfortress. The major interior exhibits include Nano, Pioneers of the Atom, Trinity and its Legacy, Hiroshima and Nagasaki, the Cold War, Energy Encounter, Nuclear Medicine, Radiation 101 and more. The Museum also hosts Little Albert’s Lab, an area where young, inquisitive minds can explore hands-on science activities.
Heritage Park, the museum’s nine-acre outdoor exhibit area, is one of the National Museum of Nuclear Science & History’s most popular attractions. With its B-52B Stratofortress, B-29 Superfortress, B-47E Stratojet, F-105D Thunderchief, A-7 Corsair II and F-16 Fighting Falcon, the museum’s collection is the largest aircraft collection for public viewing in the state of New Mexico.
The museum’s mission is “to serve as America’s resource for nuclear history and science. The museum presents exhibits and quality educational programs that convey the diversity of individuals and events that shape the historical and technical context of the nuclear age.” It is truly a place to learn, to imagine, to think and to draw your own conclusions.


 

Our Success Stories
F-105D Thunderchief and the A-7 Corsair II

Our museum's F-105D Thunderchief before Restoration.

Our museum's F-105D Thunderchief after restoration.

Our museum's A-7 Corsair II before restoration.

Our museum's A-7 Corsair II after restoration.
The most current example of the museum's aircraft restoration work can be seen in last year's Operation Preservation project that involved restoring our F-105D Thunderchief and the A-7 Corsair II. Our museum's historic F-105D Thunderchief is a supersonic fighter-bomber that was sent to Germany to provide NATO nuclear retaliation capability during the depths of the Cold War, and the museum's A-7 Corsair II is one of the Navy's most capable attack aircraft that is also the only aircraft in the museum's collection to have ever flown in combat missions.
Restoration of the two aircraft began in April of 2017 under the supervision of Restoration Project Coordinator, Brigadier General (Ret.) Jay Bledsoe, with help from museum staff and volunteers and was funded by donations received from supporters and entities with personal ties to the Museum and the historic aircraft. The museum also successfully raised over $45,000 through multiple initiatives, including an Indiegogo campaign, special events and generous support from donors and organizations. 
Restoration included the F-105D Thunderchief and the A-7 Corsair II receiving bodywork and new coats of primer and paint. Completion of these outdoor exhibits for visitor viewing took place in Winter of 2018. 
 
B-52B Stratofortress

Our museum's B-52B Stratofortress before restoration.

Our museum's B-52B Stratofortress after restoration.
The museum successfully restored its B-52B Stratofortress, s/n 52-0013, one of only a few B-models left in existence and one of only four in the world on display for public viewing, in the fall of 2016. Restoration of the B-52B began in April of 2016 under the supervision of Restoration Project Coordinator, Major Jerry Hanks, USMC (Retired), with help from museum staff and volunteers and was funded by donations received from supporters and entities with personal ties to the museum and the historic aircraft. The museum also successfully raised over $120,000 through multiple initiatives, including an Indiegogo campaign, special events and generous support from donors and organizations. 
Restoration included the B-52B receiving bodywork and a new coat of primer and paint. Completion of this outdoor exhibit for visitor viewing took place in September 2016. The museum held a dedication ceremony on Thursday, October 13, 2016, where dignitaries were present to publicly acknowledge the legacy and historical significance of the B-52B Stratofortress.
 
B-29 Superfortress

Our museum's B-29 Superfortress before restoration.

Our museum's B-29 Superfortress after restoration.
The museum successfully restored its B-29 Superfortress, one of only 17 complete aircraft of its kind left in existence, in the fall of 2015. Restoration of the B-29 began in April of 2015 under the supervision of Restoration Project Coordinator, Major Jerry Hanks, USMC (Retired), with help from museum staff and volunteers and was funded by donations received from supporters and entities with personal ties to the Museum and the historic aircraft. The museum also successfully raised over $44,000 (part of the overall cost of $110,000 needed) through a Kickstarter campaign to pay for paint and primer.
Restoration included the B-29 receiving a new coat of primer and paint, bodywork to the aircraft, new cockpit windows and the vintage 509th Wing of the Strategic Air Command paint and trim. 
The museum held a dedication ceremony on Tuesday, August 11, 2015, where dignitaries were present to publicly acknowledge the legacy and historical significance of the B-29 Superfortress.
 
F-16 Fighting Falcon

Our museum's F-16 Fighting Falcon before restoration.

Our museum's F-16 Fighting Falcon after restoration.
The museum successfully restored its F-16 Fighting Falcon in the fall of 2014. F-16 Fighting Falcons were flown by the ‘The TACOS’, the New Mexico Air National Guard 150th Fighter Wing. It was rescued from the Sandia National Laboratories Rocket Sled Track and restored for static display. The restoration included the TACO trim and tail insignia to acknowledge the 50+ year legacy and historical significance of the TACOS. The restoration even included lighting the aircraft's navigation, vertical tail illumination and landing lights.
Restoration of this iconic aircraft was supervised by Restoration Project Coordinator, Major Jerry Hanks, USMC (Retired), and was completed with the help of volunteers from Sandia National Laboratories, Kirtland Air Force Base, Museum volunteers and members of the CNM Aviation Maintenance Technology program and Service-Learning program.
The Museum held a dedication ceremony for the newly restored F-16 on November 5, 2014. U.S. Senator Martin Heinrich; U.S. Senator Tom Udall; and Brigadier General Andrew Salas, Adjutant General for the New Mexico Air National Guard were present to publicly acknowledge the restoration as well as the legacy and historical significance of the TACOS.
 
USS James K. Polk Submarine Sail

Our museum's submarine sail during restoration.

Our museum's submarine sail after restoration.
The National Museum of Nuclear Science & History successfully completed the restoration of the iconic USS James K. Polk SSN 645 nuclear submarine sail in the fall of 2014.
This truly historic object, measuring 30 feet high by nine feet wide and weighing 53 tons, was acquired by the Museum in 1999, and restoration began in the spring of 2014. Named after the 11th president of the United States, the USS James K. Polk was commissioned as SSBN 645 in 1966. The James K Polk was later converted into an attack submarine and re-designated SSN 645, making for an illustrious 33-year career.
Under the supervision of Frank Fernando, retired Process Engineer from Intel, and with help from Museum staff, volunteers and various partners, the submarine exhibit was a hub of activity throughout the summer of 2014. The completed submarine sail is now on permanent display in the Museum’s Heritage Park.
 

The Excitement
"Our B-47E is an example of the world's first swept wing jet-powered aircraft and the innovations that were created when it was invented are still with us. The B-47 represents the early jet age and the higher alert of our world during the cold war.​ It is with great excitement we move forward with this huge restoration." - Museum Executive Director, Jim Walther
"I love to see our airplanes returned to their former glory! Our B-47 is an iconic airplane; a strategic nuclear bomber that was flown at high altitude and subsonic speed by the United States Air Force Strategic Air Command. Of the 2032 Stratojets built by Boeing, only 23 survive today. Our aircraft restoration projects are an exciting way to motivate children and adults to be excited about history, science, technology, engineering and math." - Museum Registrar, Sandy Fye
"Some of my earliest recollections, beside chasing after various desert creatures, playing in our back yard grass, and gathering with multiple neighborhood kids to play, include watching the entire wing of USAF’s 303rd Bomb Wing, flying B-47’s based at Davis Monthan AFB, sequentially start engines, squadron-by-squadron and takeoff for a long deployment. Since my father was the navigator of one of these beasts, scheduled to deploy with the entire wing to Guam for training, my mother took me and my siblings to the base to watch the mass departure.
Other wives and mothers were likewise attending while stewarding their charges as congruently as my Mom and in the same viewing area set up for this event. And what a spectacle it was! Each of the three squadrons had a different colored stripe on the tail, to denote that squadron, added color to the show. Start-up sounds of the 270 engines of the 45 aircraft were deafening. Slowly but deliberately, the sleek bombers taxied out to the runway for takeoff. One jet at a time, the silver-colored spears rolled down the long runway, eventually lifting off, trailing six streams of black smoke as they followed one after the other, roaring into the distant Arizona morning sky. Jet after silver jet blasted down the runway, lifting and following the same path to join together many miles away and far from our sight.
Perhaps this is one reason I decided to become a USAF pilot many years later, flying into this same grey-blue sky; off to adventure, challenge, and danger, just as these B-47 crews did some 30 years before, I was flying jets that only a vivid imagination could conjure back in 1957. The B-47’s were retired many years ago, yet the B-47 still holds a vivid and special place in my memory." - Jay Bledsoe, Brig Gen, USAF (Ret)​
 

Your Support, Our Gratitude

The National Museum of Nuclear Science & History staff, Board of Trustees and volunteers all passionately believe in the mission of our museum, and we know its past and future success depends on the generosity of our donors, volunteers and supporters.  Our heartfelt thanks go out to all of you.
Operation Preservation, The Campaign to Restore the Planes in Heritage Park is a massive undertaking, with the B-47E Stratojet being only one of the seven aircraft needing to be restored.  It would be impossible for the museum to consider such a project without the confidence that generous donors will supply the bulk of the funding, and generous volunteers will supply the thousands of man-hours necessary to restore the aircraft. 
Thank you all.
 

Risks & Challenges
The largest risk to this project is in not having the aircraft sufficiently restored so that it can be dedicated in the Fall of 2018. At a minimum, this means the aircraft must be fully painted. For this to happen, the funding must be secured, the body work must be completed, the primer and paint applied and insignias painted.
Mitigation strategies that have been put in place include a schedule that includes time for unknowns such as weather and fluctuation in manpower. In addition, work to secure funds and manpower was started in mid-2017.
Overall, there is little risk that the project will not be completed. The restoration of the B-47E Stratojet is the museum's top priority in 2018, and the museum has an excellent track record of completing aircraft projects. The largest, completed between 2009 and 2011, was the relocation of all aircraft and other Heritage Park exhibits from the museum's first home, when it was located on Kirtland Air Force Base, to its current location. More recently, the museum successfully completed the full restoration of the F-105D Thunderchief, the A-7 Corsair II, the B-52B Stratofortress, the B-29 Superfortress, the F-16 Fighting Falcon and the USS James K. Polk SSN 645 nuclear submarine sail.
 
Thank you for your time and consideration!

story:
Can you help us raise $3,500 in 35 days?
 
We believe in creating access to technology in order to break the cycle of poverty. As a program of Southwest Youth and Family Services, our mission is to partner with youth and families to transform their futures. 
 
We are New Futures, 3 family centers located in Southwest Seattle, (White Center, Burien, and SeaTac). We run an after-school program in the heart of King County Housing Authority, serving over 190 kids from preschool to high school. We provide a safe and welcoming place for our students and their families, 97% of whom are immigrants and refugees.
 
Over the past year we have developed a coding and robotics program at one of our site in SeaTac and the results have been incredible! Greater student engagement, higher literacy levels, and kids are learning computational thinking. Students are learning how to code, create apps, build robots and data science. 
 
You can help us raise enough funds so we can make this happen at all our sites! What does that look like? Your donation will be used to purchase 16 new laptop computers as well as train and build a robust robotics curriculum with our staff. You can help 165 kids from 1st to12th grade learn the technology skills they’ll need to compete in our tech-driven society.
 
As Seattle’s landscape continues to change, it is critical that we provide technological education to families who are the most vulnerable to pressures of gentrification and displacement. Help us build a new future for our students and families!

story:
Six years ago this week, we completed an experiment that took 13 kids from the Ocean Alternative School and put them in front of a working, professional artist. The sculpture they created is now the centerpiece at the NextSpace Coworking location on Cooper Street in downtown Santa Cruz. Forage Species was a hugely successful attempt to use art and high-caliber artists to teach the biology of the Monterey Bay and to create material for a writing project. It worked – far beyond our expectations.
 
We now begin the task of creating a working Social B corporation that will put art back into the classroom where any teacher who wants to participate, can utilize this methodology to engage their students in Core, STEM material. Any student, any teacher, in any classroom, anywhere. We are poised to deliver critical thinking and problem solving instruction on a national level – but we need your help.

We need you to help us smash this launch by investing just $100 in our powerful new tool so we will begin building it for our teachers, schools, kids and communities. We are looking for 100 people to invest $100 in our web-based program that allow us to put art and art-based, project-centered learning back into the daily education experience of every kid in the U.S.

We will use the money raised to launch the company by building the web infrastructure that will deliver this material to anyone who wants to use it.
 
We know it works.
We know the kids and teachers need it.
We know that kids learn better when they have it.
And we know that we can deliver it quickly and effectively.

Please be one of the first to help us put critical thinking skills back into our educational matrix – we can do this.

Visit us on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/smart2gousa/  and please share the link to this campaign with your social media networks https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/smart2go-art...

Thank you for the support!

story:
The 'Black Queens Matter' campaign was created and founded by Music Artist and Video Director Ridock King (www.ridockking.com), this campaign will help raise funds for the female enrichment organization "Beaute' Within" as well as for a music and film project inspired by the need to have a positive impact on young black girls.
There is a significant need for positive role models in the lives of young black girls, some of the radio and media messages can be very misleading. It is time that we take it upon ourselves to encourage young black girls that they are queens and that there lies within them the potential to help bring about positive societal change.
Black Queens Matter is not an exclusion of any other race of girls, but it is an emphasis on the urgent needs of young black girls. We believe all girls require encouragement, mentoring, and assistance, but we feel it is very necessary to focus on black girls. There are voids that are left within the black community from various issues ranging from 'no father in home' to 'lack of resources.' The family plays a key role in the success or failure of these young girls but we all understand that things happen and sometimes a black girl may not have a dependable family.

We are fortunate to have organizations that will help with encouraging, mentoring and assisting young girls. Black girls deserve a fair shot, we understand that there is an incomparable amount of pressure on families and schools to help these young girls realize their full potential. As the old saying goes "it takes a village to raise a child" it will take organizations, artists, and visionaries working together to see that young black girls understand that they too matter!


All donations given will go towards the Black Queens Matter campaign to help with expenses for female enrichment organization, and for special projects designed for the same cause. There are several perks for donations, depending on the amount given:


What We Need & What You Get

  • This campaign will require funding. The expenses incurred will be as followed:
  • Film Project = $1500
  • 'Beaute Within' Expenses (Travel, Food, Supplies, young women empowerment events, guest speakers) = $1800
  • Marketing and Promotion = $400
  • Production Equipment and Software = $425
  • Expense Total = $4125
  • Total Needed to Raise = $2500

  • For those who may be interested in receiving a perk for donations, we have generated a list of perks: (Each perk also includes the previous perk(s) listed)
  • Premiere of film DVD = $30.00
  • Special thank you email = $55.00
  • T-Shirt (Black Queens Matter, or Dream, Plan, Execute) = $100.00
  • 2 tickets to empowerment event = $150.00
  • Special thanks at end of film = $250.00
  • Invitation to appear in film (great opportunity to expose your brand) = $325.00
  • Executive director credit = $400.00
  • Personalized poem and song by Ridock King (Topic of your choice) = $475.00

  • We are very optimistic about this campaign and we know that with the right support there is no doubt we will reach our goal. Most of us believe that now is the time to bring about real change instead of simply complaining and discussing this change. We have been hearing and speaking about it for quite a while and now is the time, you as a supporter will now have the opportunity to help induce this change, and be a part of something greater than our individual selves. If we do not reach our goal the campaign ends and there is a 9% charge on total amount raised and there are no refunds given to donors. If that happens we will have let down many young women who deserve better. However, we are extremely optimistic that such will not be the case, and that your will and tenacity to help bring about real change to our community will ultimately be unmatched. We will meet our goal because we all agree that black queens matter.

The Impact

  • As a contributor and supporter of this campaign you will have played a major part in the cultivation of real positive change for young women, and like many of us you are probably thinking that now is the perfect time. 
  • As an artist I have continuously challenged the status quo and creatively engineered visually and through audio a different perspective, a perfect example of this would be my song and music video titled "Oshun".
  • You can count on this campaign to deliver, but the bigger question is can those young women count on you to deliver, this is not about any one individual, but this is much bigger and this opportunity has the potential to save many young lives. 

Risks & Challenges

  • Like many things in life this campaign will not be easy, but with the proper support we will make this happen. 
  • We will use all possible avenues of promotion and out-reach so that we may help exhaust any and all potential to come up short of our goal. 
  • Other Ways You Can Help
  • If you cannot contribute financially I would ask if you could help spread the word of this extraordinary campaign.
  • Please be sure to use the Indiegogo share tools

It is time to take a stand and be a part of something great, BLACK QUEENS MATTER!

Black girls deserve a fair shot, we understand that there is an incomparable amount of pressure on families and schools to help these young girls realize their full potential. As the old saying goes "it takes a village to raise a child" it will take organizations, artists, and visionaries working together to see that young black girls understand that they too matter! 
All donations given will go towards the Black Queens Matter campaign to help with expenses for female enrichment organization, and for special projects designed for the same cause. There are several perks for donations, depending on the amount given:

   What We Need & What You Get  This campaign will require funding. The expenses incurred will be as followed: 

Film Project = $1500
'Beaute Within' Expenses (Travel, Food, Supplies, young women empowerment events, guest speakers) = $1800
Marketing and Promotion = $400
Production Equipment and Software = $425
Expense Total = $4125
Total Needed to Raise = $2500
 For those who may be interested in receiving a perk for donations, we have generated a list of perks: (Each perk also includes the previous perk(s) listed)

Premiere of film DVD = $30.00

Special thank you email = $55.00
T-Shirt (Black Queens Matter, or Dream, Plan, Execute) = $100.00
2 tickets to empowerment event = $150.00
Special thanks at end of film = $250.00 

Invitation to appear in film (great opportunity to expose your brand) = $325.00
Executive director credit = $400.00 

Personalized poem and song by Ridock King (Topic of your choice) = $475.00 

 We are very optimistic about this campaign and we know that with the right support there is no doubt we will reach our goal. Most of us believe that now is the time to bring about real change instead of simply complaining and discussing this change. We have been hearing and speaking about it for quite a while and now is the time, you as a supporter will now have the opportunity to help induce this change, and be a part of something greater than our individual selves. If we do not reach our goal the campaign ends and there is a 9% charge on total amount raised and there are no refunds given to donors. If that happens we will have let down many young women who deserve better. However, we are extremely optimistic that such will not be the case, and that your will and tenacity to help bring about real change to our community will ultimately be unmatched. We will meet our goal because we all agree that black queens matter. 
    The Impact  As a contributor and supporter of this campaign you will have played a major part in the cultivation of real positive change for young women, and like many of us you are probably thinking that now is the perfect time.  As an artist I have continuously challenged the status quo and creatively engineered visually and through audio a different perspective, a perfect example of this would be my song and music video titled "Oshun". You can count on this campaign to deliver, but the bigger question is can those young women count on you to deliver, this is not about any one individual, but this is much bigger and this opportunity has the potential to save many young lives.     Risks & Challenges  Like many things in life this campaign will not be easy, but with the proper support we will make this happen. 
We will use all possible avenues of promotion and out-reach so that we may help exhaust any and all potential to come up short of our goal. 

Other Ways You Can Help
  If you cannot contribute financially I would ask if you could help spread the word of this extraordinary campaign. Please be sure to use the Indiegogo share tools

It is time to take a stand and be a part of something great, BLACK QUEENS MATTER!

story:
¿De qué se trata?

Porque creemos que los sueños y el trabajo por un mundo mejor no acaban cuando sales de la Universidad o de AIESEC…

AIESEC Alumni Colombia (AAC) ha conformado una delegación latinoamericana para la Millennium Campus Conference (MCC) que se llevará a cabo en la Organización de las Naciones Unidas en Ciudad de Nueva York del 11 al 15 de agosto de 2015. 

El evento es organizado por Millennium Campus Network, un nodo de organizaciones que trabajan en pro del desarrollo y la superación de la pobreza en el mundo. Contará con la asistencia de cientos de líderes jóvenes, así como directivos de instituciones privadas, públicas y civiles de todas las regiones del mundo. AIESEC es Co-Chair del evento.

¿Por qué es importante para nosotros?

Este 2015 representa el hito de los Objetivos de Desarrollo del Milenio 2000-2015 y será el año donde la Asamblea General de la ONU definirá los nuevos Objetivos de Desarrollo Sostenible para 2015-2030. La histórica cumbre de MCC convocará estudiantes y líderes jóvenes de más de 50 naciones para construir alianzas en el movimiento para promover los Objetivos de Desarrollo Sostenible de las Naciones Unidas.

Para representar a AIESEC Alumni en este evento tan relevante, hemos conformado un delegación de 20 alumni jóvenes (menores de 35 años), todos apasionados y abanderados de causas e iniciativas públicas, de desarrollo y/o de emprendimiento social.

Creemos que esta oportunidad nos puede conectar con ideas extraordinarias, además de darle un impulso a nuestras iniciativas personales y profesionales enfocadas en el desarrollo social de nuestra región. 

¿Qué necesitamos?

Cada delegado es responsable por los costos de su asistencia a la conferencia que incluyen fee del evento de USD 200 (cuatro días), pasaje a NYC y viáticos de estadía durante los días del evento. 

Esta campaña de crowdfunding es una ayuda para conseguir recursos de co-financiación de los gastos de fee del evento y pasaje de los delegados que aún no los tienen cubiertos.

Estamos seguros que habiendo ganas, el dinero para asistir se puede conseguir con esfuerzos individuales y colectivos.  Y por eso recurrimos a tu ayuda. 

Algunos de nosotros en nuestra primera reunión de planeación de delegación en Bogotá. 


¿Quiénes somos?

  • Catalina Henao. Directora estratégica Fundación Tin Tin Corre Corre. Asesora Secretaría de Educación, Colombia.
  • Nazly Frías. Asesora política pública de Innovación Social. Departamento Nacional de Planeación, Colombia. 
  • Alejandra Laiton Galán. Co-fundadora y directora de programas sociales digitales en RUBICA Consultores, Colombia. 
  • Andrés Julian Triana Rivera. Asesor Estrategia de Inclusión Productiva Rural - Dirección de Inclusión Productiva y Sostenibilidad Departamento para la Prosperidad Social, Colombia.
  • Daniel Londoño Estrada. Asesor de Presidencia, Fondo Nacional del Ahorro, Colombia.
  • Liliana Maria Solano. Asesora Agencia Nacional para la Superación de la Pobreza Extrema. Departamento para la Prosperidad Social, Colombia.
  • Santiago Pulido Gómez. Asesor de Política Macroeconómica, Ministerio de Hacienda y Crédito Público, Colombia.
  • Mariadelaida Uribe de Plaza. Secretaría de Educación del Distrito en convenio con AIESEC en Colombia, proyecto Aulas de Inmersión, Colombia.
  • Luz Helena Carreño Nuñez. Emprendedora Scarf Store, Colombia.
  • Mauricio Agudelo. Director y socio fundador Estrativa, Colombia.
  • Javier Quiroga. ProColombia, Colombia. 
  • Ana María Vela. Directora comercial, Edge Talent for Impactful Business Across Emerging Markets, Colombia. 
  • Camilo Andres Cupitre Aldana. National Cancer Council Malaysia, Colombia.
  • Daniel Henao Tobón. Director Luxdey, Colombia
  • Maryoth Vanessa Sainea Camargo. Asistente y voluntaria. Fundación Tin Tin Corre Corre, Colombia.
  • Sara Carolina Rendon Franco. Directora, Fundación Tin Tin Corre Corre
  • Luis Gabriel Poveda. Fundador, Incubadora de Seguridad Alimentaria y Desarrollo Rural, Colombia. 
  • Ana Gabriela Perez. Asesora, Programa Nacional de Competitivadad, Guatemala 
  • María Fernanda Visintini. Manager Hydroscada, Chile
  • Caíque Diniz Ribeiro. Coaching and Leadership Caique Diniz, Brasil. 
  • Janelle Liceaga. Manager Boricua Tenants in Action (IBA). Puerto Rico.
  • Helena Toro Walker. Associate Citgo Group of Companies. United States.


Con el apoyo de:

Camilo Andres Cupitre Aldana. National Cancer Council Malaysia, Colombia.


Daniel Henao Tobón. Director Luxdey, Colombia

Maryoth Vanessa Sainea Camargo. Asistente y voluntaria. Fundación Tin Tin Corre Corre, Colombia.
Sara Carolina Rendon Franco. Directora, Fundación Tin Tin Corre Corre

Luis Gabriel Poveda. Fundador, Incubadora de Seguridad Alimentaria y Desarrollo Rural, Colombia. 

Ana Gabriela Perez. Asesora, Programa Nacional de Competitivadad, Guatemala 

María Fernanda Visintini. Manager Hydroscada, Chile

story:
About People To People

Founded in 1999 and recognized as a 501(c)(3) tax-exempt organization in the United States, People to  People (P2P) is a non-governmental, non-profit organization dedicated to improving health care and reducing the spread of diseases, particularly in Ethiopia and in diaspora communities.   There are currently more than 5,000 P2P members worldwide, including doctors and other professionals who strive to make a difference in the lives of others.  Our network stands ready to take on many of the challenges facing communities and institutions in Ethiopia and elsewhere.

P2P’s projects are focused on strengthening health systems through partnerships with local hospitals and universities, in which we engage the global Ethiopian diaspora in an attempt to bridge the knowledge gap and address the country’s severe shortage of health and medical professionals.  P2P is also engaged in a number of service-oriented projects, working in particular with vulnerable  communities, such as children orphaned by HIV/AIDS, the elderly, the deaf community, women, and more, devoting our time and effort to their overall health and empowerment.

How your funding will support P2P

People to People (P2P) stands uniquely poised to undertake meaningful development work in Ethiopia and help to address the many challenges faced by its resilient people.  People to Peoples (P2P) vision is in developing Ethiopia’s human resources capital, health care and education thereby bringing Ethiopia  truly into the 21st century.

People to People (P2P) and The Network of Ethiopian diaspora healthcare Professionals announce the  7Th Annual Global Ethiopian Diaspora conference on Health Care and Medical Education.  Saturday, September 26th 2015 in The Washington, DC metro Area.  Key Topics will include:

  1. Disaster Management and Response  (Focus on the Ebola Epidemic Management)
  2. Injury and Trauma in the Ethiopian Setting
  3. New Licensure Exam and requirements for medical school graduates and physicians in Ethiopia
  4. Diaspora Partnership projects relevant to Ethiopia
  5. Abstract and Poster Presentations on health related topics relevant to Ethiopia

Your help to P2P will allow cover the following expenses: 

  • Travel  expense for staff, special guests, foreign attendees
  • Pay for  accommodations.
  • Rent for  conference facility (Venue Rental, equipment and etc)

P2P is very proud that this annual event, which was started amid lots of uncertainties, is turning out to be the go to conference for those who are collaborating with Ethiopian healthcare institutions.  In addition, it is serving as a successful venue for bringing together Ethiopian Diaspora Health Care professionals to discuss and debate issues relevant to Health Care and medical Education in Ethiopia.  It is also serving as means of connecting the Diaspora with Ethiopian Health Care Institutions and  facilitating the transfer of knowledge, technology and investment.

Risks & Challenges

Improving  the health, education, and success of millions of people entangled in poverty, particularly in Ethiopia is a daunting task however  the magnitude of the problem is not a valid reason to shy away from what may feel like overwhelming circumstances. There is fear and uncertainty struck in the hearts of all those who have been and are affected by sickness and poverty.  It's our responsibility to  provide   them with the tools and resources they need to succeed – both of which they are unable to obtain by their own means.

story:
Update: see http://quizster.co to start using Quizster now.

 

Why?

My wife has been teaching for 10 years and really cares about her students. As part of her weekly routine implementing formative assessment, she spends a lot of time grading. As a software developer, I'm obsessed with streamlining processes such as the feedback cycle in formative assessment. Quizster is our attempt to make this process more efficient, so that teachers can focus their energy on the quality of their feedback.​

Geoff Cox, Co-Founder of Quizster

 

A proven track record

Quizster is currently being used by over 100 students on an almost daily basis. Each day these students submit dozens of assignments and in turn, these assignments are graded directly in the app. Students then resubmit their work and teachers re-grade it until the student has mastered the skill. These students and their teachers have come to think of Quizster as an essential tool in their classrooms.

Here is what some teachers are saying about Quizster:

Before Quizster, I had two problems: I was limited to where and when I could grade and I was unable to give students feedback in a timely manner. Now, I use my phone, tablet, or laptop to grade as soon as students submit work. I know where students are at with the material at any given moment. Furthermore, my students and I can dialogue electronically, one-on-one, about their misconceptions and needs for improved understanding. Quizster has helped me tighten the links of communication in a way I could have never imagined​.

Danielle Maletta, High School Math Teacher and NBCT

 

Quizster is so easy to use, it has made the grading process a cinch and something that I actually look forward to! It is a one-stop shop for collecting formative assignments, evaluating and recording the results, returning the assignments with helpful annotations, and putting the ball back in the student’s court for showing me further improvement. It has made a direct impact on student learning.

Read more about Mimi's story

Mimi Yang, High School Math Teacher and Co-Founder of Quizster

 

How will your contributions help?

Your contributions will help bring Quizster to more students and teachers. Quizster facilitates learning through dialogue, which reinforces students’ skills while encouraging these students to embrace a growth mindset. Teachers spend less time grading as Quizster’s notifications and general organization streamline the grading process. Moreover, teachers won’t have to lug huge bags of notebooks and papers around as all the work is available via any of their personal devices.

Using the funds raised by this campaign we'll be able to continue developing Quizster and ensure that it has the features needed by a larger audience of teachers and students. The funds will also go towards hardware costs associated with running the system.

 

Know a teacher that this could help?

The perks are transferrable and the service could really make a difference in a teacher's classroom and in their students' learning. We’d also love for you to help us spread the word by sharing this campaign with teachers and other educators via the Facebook, Twitter, Indiegogo and email links above.

 

About the founder

Geoff Cox has been developing software professionally for over 15 years. In this time, he has founded a number of popular software systems. GoExpo, his last project, processes hundreds of millions of dollars a year for the trade show industry. Geoff is married to a teacher of 10 years and is passionate about improving her work-life balance.

 

More info

https://quizster.co

 

What is formative assessment?

story:
http://www.zmolu.com

 

HerRedCarpet.com came about when I was looking for an online site like this and it didn’t exist.  After a cultural South Asian wedding I thought would it not be great instead of buying these beautiful clothes every year to only wear a few times, why not

CREATE A COMMUNITY WHERE WE CAN RECYCLE AND REUSE BY SELLING, BUYING AND EXCHANGING FROM OUR OWN SOUTH ASIAN CLOSET

The South Asian population is one of the largest demographics in the world and within it’s rich culture there are so many celebrations and lots of outfits are purchased every year. HerRedCarpet.com helps solve an issue.

100% of the funding will go to Marketing and Promotion that is where we need it the most. We need you to make this happen. 

We often talk about over consumption and it has become an economical concern globally, Her Red Carpet helps this cause by reducing consumption.

On our site you can buy, sell, request to exchange or counter offer. Counter offer is first of it’s kind and we are excited to introduce it to the world.

Of course being able to contribute and helping us reach our goal would be much appreciated, but Her Red Carpet’s success depends on the continuous help from the community.

 

Help us by participating on our social media 

 

You efforts won’t go unnoticed. The more you #hashtag us the more we get our online community to be recognized by a larger audience.

For our loyal followers who’ll #herredcarpet on a regular basis we have prizes which of course we would love to give away and see you smile.  

Every one person counts (yes you) and every click matters.

So let’s bring HerRedCarpet.com to life !

story:
Kelev Ra Training Group and Range

My name is Alex Steitz, welcome to Kelev Ra Training Group LLC. I founded Kelev Ra Training Group LLC to bring my love of teaching, coaching, and the disciplines of marksmanship to those around me. I am a NRA certified pistol instructor and range safety officer, I am also a Marine that loves challenging myself in new ways. As I travel the Front Range teaching classes I have seen that there are no options open, to the general public, that combine both indoor and outdoor facilities, with a flexibility to practice multiple disciplines of marksmanship and self-defense training. To accomplish this currently one would need at least 2 sometimes 3 separate memberships to cover their training needs, at a cost of over $1000 annually.   This spawned my Idea to bring them all together. By the time the Kelev Ra Training Group Range Facilities are complete the community will have a one stop shop for: learning to shoot pistol, rifle, and shotgun; competition shooting in the same; long range rifle (with targets out to 1000 yards); tactical ranges; hunting practice areas; archery; paintball and air-soft fields; indoor ranges; martial arts gyms and instruction; pro-shops and lounges; and most importantly a friendly and welcoming community. 

What We Need & What You Get

$1.5 million is a large and somewhat scary number especially for an individual. I'll admit when pricing out the options for making this dream a reality it this number was almost crushing. That being said the journey of 1,000 miles begins with one step. This is that first step. While $1.5 Million is the estimated cost for the full project, even modest amounts start this journey as they can help pay for the proper certifications and licenses required to make this project a success. Phase 1 includes buying the land, and building the first outdoor facilites. The project finishes in phase 5 with a fully developed lounge and range-house featuring a restaurant and entertainment area. Like the perks listed below each phase builds in scale and opportunity.  

The Impact

This facility has the unique opportunity to bring every training need into one facility while keeping the costs low. The diversity of opportunity that this facility brings will allow membership rates to be over 25% less than single option training facilities. The average monthly dues for indoor ranges in Colorado are $30, at Kelev Ra Training Group they will be a low $20, and even lower as the length of the membership is extended. Daily there will be a variety of class and public training options, with a multitude of facilities for private training opportunities as well. Safety, fun, and flexibility will be hallmarks of the Kelev Ra Training Group Range facility.  

Risks & Challenges

Training with firearms can be dangerous if not done at proper facilities and with proper precaution. There is one thing the military (especially the Marine Corps) trains all new recruits to do and that is safely handle firearms on a range. As a veteran owned and operated facility we will bring these safety standards and  vigilance to the range, without the drill instructor intimidation factor. Rules will be clearly displayed and politely, though strictly enforced. All facilities will be engineered to provide the maximum effectiveness in each training environment. Range personnel will be certified and will receive regular refresher training to supplement their own range time. This extra attention to detail will provide the necessary precaution to ensure a safe and fun day at the range. 

Colorado presents a unique set of challenges to opening range facilities like the one envisioned for Kelev Ra Training Group. With land prices soaring as the major cities expand, any delays in this process increases start up costs and challenge the accessibility of the range. This campaign is meant to jump start the process of acquiring the land required to safely operate these facilities. We are keeping a keen eye out for properties that can easily serve the Denver and Colorado Springs Metropolitan areas, as well as the eastern plains, to be able to take advantage of opportunities as they become available. Your generous contributions will allow us to achieve this mission. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Money isn't everything in life. If times are tough and money is not something you can part with, we always appreciate you sharing our goals with anyone you know who may be interested in our services. Your time and support will go a long way in helping to achieve the goals we've laid out. 

 I want to extend a sincere and hearty thank you for your time and consideration. We at Kelev Ra Training Group look forward to serving you now and in the future. 

Semper Fidelis, 

Alex Steitz, Owner
story_txt:
Kelev Ra Training Group and Range My name is Alex Steitz, welcome to Kelev Ra Training Group LLC. I founded Kelev Ra Training Group LLC to bring my love of teaching, coaching, and the disciplines of marksmanship to those around me. I am a NRA certified pistol instructor and range safety officer, I am also a Marine that loves challenging myself in new ways. As I travel the Front Range teaching classes I have seen that there are no options open, to the general public, that combine both indoor and outdoor facilities, with a flexibility to practice multiple disciplines of marksmanship and self-defense training. To accomplish this currently one would need at least 2 sometimes 3 separate memberships to cover their training needs, at a cost of over $1000 annually.   This spawned my Idea to bring them all together. By the time the Kelev Ra Training Group Range Facilities are complete the community will have a one stop shop for: learning to shoot pistol, rifle, and shotgun; competition shooting in the same; long range rifle (with targets out to 1000 yards); tactical ranges; hunting practice areas; archery; paintball and air-soft fields; indoor ranges; martial arts gyms and instruction; pro-shops and lounges; and most importantly a friendly and welcoming community.    What We Need & What You Get $1.5 million is a large and somewhat scary number especially for an individual. I'll admit when pricing out the options for making this dream a reality it this number was almost crushing. That being said the journey of 1,000 miles begins with one step. This is that first step. While $1.5 Million is the estimated cost for the full project, even modest amounts start this journey as they can help pay for the proper certifications and licenses required to make this project a success. Phase 1 includes buying the land, and building the first outdoor facilites. The project finishes in phase 5 with a fully developed lounge and range-house featuring a restaurant and entertainment area. Like the perks listed below each phase builds in scale and opportunity.  
The Impact
 This facility has the unique opportunity to bring every training need into one facility while keeping the costs low. The diversity of opportunity that this facility brings will allow membership rates to be over 25% less than single option training facilities. The average monthly dues for indoor ranges in Colorado are $30, at Kelev Ra Training Group they will be a low $20, and even lower as the length of the membership is extended. Your time and support will go a long way in helping to achieve the goals we've laid out.

Alex Steitz, Owner

story:
Hello to you all!

So my name is Prince Amponsah and in November of 2012, I was caught in a tragic house fire which burned 68% of my body and which also led to the amputation of parts of both of my arms. What came next was 9 months of multiple surgeries and recovery followed by nearly two years of rehabilitation. It's been an uphill battle but I'm proud to say I feel stronger and I am more than glad for a second chance at life. This isn't my first time on indiegogo, when the accident happened back in 2012, I was fortunate enough to have my friends immediately rally together to start crowdfunding to raise nearly $30,000. Those funds were used towards purchasing a prosthetic arm for my left arm. 

Now I've started another crowdfunding campaign to raise funds for hopefully more advanced prosthetic arms as well as funds toward my tuition as I begin university this fall for social work.

Any amount is greatly appreciated and I thank everyone for their continued support.

story:
Selling Plants, Learning Skills, Raising Money, Helping the Planet.

We are kids in Washington, DC who want to make the future a better place with more plants and educate other people about plants. 

  • Max Heckscher is the Sprout Master and some of his friends in the neighborhood and at Hearst Elementary School are involved with the help of Max's dad
  • We are helping earn money and raise money for good causes by doing good things and it is important because people can learn from it.
  • People will benefit by having a good looking and good tasting garden if they buy plants from Thousand Sprouts.

You can buy peppers, basil, tomatoes, chives, catnip, lettuce, cilantro, and lots more. Heirloom and hybrids available. Pick up is at 1214 Irving St NW, 20010 or Hearst Elementary School. Delivery available for larger orders in Washington, DC.


To support this campaign, buy plants. Then you will get delicious herbs and vegetables.

  • 25% of funds raised will be donated to Hearst Elementary School, a public school in Washington, DC
  • 25% will support kids programs at BloomBars, an arts and cultural space in Columbia Heights, DC
  • 10% cover costs such as seeds, soil, and planters, as well as the Indiegogo fees
  • 40% goes to the kids involved

The Impact

  • Inspires people
  • Gives people many wonderful plants
  • Kids learn about how to be a gardener and take care of plants

Timeline for Pickups and Special Events

Additional drop off and delivery can be arranged by email. Dates may change due to weather and unforeseen events:

At Hearst from 330 to 5:30, pick up plants

Fri, May 27
Wed, June 1
Wed, June 8

Sundays at 1214 Irving St NW Washington, DC 20010, time TBD

Sun, May 29
Sun, June 12

We will email pick up details to all those who buy plants. 

Thanks for your support!

story:
Why the need?

  • Schools continue to have budget shortfalls 
  • Teachers are paying for classroom essentials out of their own pockets- $$$
  • Teachers do a lot of hard work and we want to shower them with gratitude
  • Traditional product fundraisers give very low percentages back to schools
  • Parents and community members need an EASY way to donate to schools 


Why Indiegogo?

We think this is a great idea, but people usually think their own ideas are great. We want to know what YOU think. If you think the idea has legs, fund us at any level. Every $1 helps. If you can't fund us today, tell AS MANY people about us as you can.


What's a CHIKAGRAM ?


  • A 15 second video Thank you card for your Teacher or school staff member.
  • For just $5 your teacher will receive a personalized email that will direct them to a link to view your Chikagram. Your Chikagram will be displayed on the Chikamon.com wall of greatness, as well as our Social media platforms like Linkedin, Facebook, Pinterest , and Instagram
  • Along with Nationwide recognition for your teacher, your school will receive 50% of all proceeds.

What's in the box?

GIFTS for relaxation - We also have a line of handcrafted gifts, specifically created with relaxation in mind. Hot/Cold shoulder pads, Sugar scrubs, Salt scrubs, Relaxing Bath Salts, Cooling foot soaks and more.

Donations- For those donors who would prefer to give money directly to their school of choice, we make it easy for schools to accept credit or debit card donations.  

Chikamon Swag - We have all types of swag like our SUPER Teacher window decal- " I teach...What's your super power"

The Money

We run a tight ship. We also do great things with a tight budget. We aim to always keep overhead as low as possible, so that we can continue to give larger profits back to the schools we serve. Our initial goal is small, though if our campaign is funded at higher levels we will be able to do the following:

We need $2,500 to run our CHIKAGRAM program successfully.   (Indiegogo fees included) 

Reaching the Goal of $5,000 would allow us to continue the Chikamon Relax Pack program locally. 

Reaching the Goal of $20,000 would allow us to run the Chikamon Relax Pack program nationally, as well as expand our product line

Reaching the Goal of $50,000 would allow us to run our fully envisioned program nationally. We would also be able to build out the donation portion of our website.  

The Impact

Teachers will receive less homemade Pinterest fails, but still have gifts with a more personal touch.

Schools will have a fundraiser that it simple to use, zero setup time, which yields more profit for their kids.

Our Backstory?

I couldn't stand product fundraisers as a child. I didn't have family members that were able or willing to buy tons of product from the catalogs I brought home. My single mother often felt obligated to purchase something so that I could get the prizes that we were "sold on". Even as a kid I realized that they were never worth the money. Then in track I sold chocolate in the summers in the hood and honestly my friends and I ate way more melted chocolate than we sold. Then our parents had to bail us out by paying the difference. When my younger sisters were in elementary YEARS later I saw them come home with the same old catalogs. When neighborhood kids came looking for school support I was more willing and able to give money, but I wished there was an easy way for me to give directly to their school and I didn't trust giving cash that could be lost or used at the corner store. Now as the parents of a first grader, we are faced with the need for fundraisers again at our local school. It is time to take real action. Chikamon is a company that we feel really good about representing. No more products I don't want or need, Supporting schools and parent groups directly. Products that make teachers feel amazing!


What’s our schedule?

We will begin posting CHIKAGRAMS at the beginning of the 2016-2017 school year; following our successful project funding. We want to see teachers and school staff coming back in the fall to start the year off feeling GREAT about their jobs. 

Our Chikamon Relax Packs will be shipped by November 2016. This is the fall fundraising season.  We have already sourced and purchased materials. We do not foresee any delays in fulfillment. 

More you say ?

 Chikamon.com is a unique fundraising platform designed for public & private schools. Instead of participating in fundraisers that give only 10% - 20% of their profits to schools, we are committed to giving MORE. Our goal is to give 50% - 60% of product profits back to schools. And 100% of donations will be given to schools (minus card processing fees) 

We give parents and community members tools to support schools while showing appreciation for their favorite teachers and school staff.

     We want to flood our nation's schools with CHIKAMON love!!! 

      We are not a retailer that dabbles in school fundraising as a subset of the company. We developed our company with the goal teacher appreciation paired with better school fundraising. After being involved with school support groups (PTA/ PTO/ PTSA) for several years, we have learned that many schools rely on product fundraisers to bring in the money necessary to cover essential school operations. 

   Please support our dream of helping schools in a substantial way. 


Risks & Challenges

Project may become challenging if we receive an overwhelming number of CHIKAGRAM requests and are unable to review and post each video in a timely fashion

WE WILL NOT POST NEGATIVE OR DISPARAGING VIDEOS if we receive inappropriate videos (containing negative comments, or profanity or otherwise deemed unfit for all ages) the video will not be posted and a refund WILL NOT be given


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, but believe in our campaign you can still help us:

  • Make some noise - tell as many people as you know about CHIKAMON- 
  • Use the SHARE buttons on our page to post us on your social media sites
  • Send us feedback, we welcome any and all ideas you have to improve CHIKAMON
